_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Chlorine is the most commonly used substance for disinfecting drinking water.  The addition of chlorine or chlorine compounds to water is called chlorination.  Chlorination is considered to be the most important process for preventing the spread of waterborne disease in drinking water.  The Los Angeles Department of Water and Power (LADWP) also uses chlorine for drinking water disinfection purposes to protect public health per state and federal water quality standards. Storing and handling large quantities of chlorine can create hazardous situations.  The LADWP takes safety obligations in storing and using chlorine as seriously as it takes in providing safe drinking water. The LADWP Eagle Rock Reservoir Outlet Chlorination Station chlorine handling process is subject to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program and Plan and also to the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program requirements.  The facilities subject to the EPA and the CalARP regulations are required to prepare and update Risk Management Plans (RMPs).  The RMP is to include policies and procedures followed to safely operate the facility and the actions, which will be taken by the facility in an event of an emergency.  The LADWP prepared and submitted RMPs for the Eagle Rock Reservoir Outlet Chlorination Station in June 1999, June 2004, and June 2009. This RMP is the five-year update of the June 2009 RMP. The LADWP prepared Program Level 2 RMPS in 1999 and 2004 because Eagle Rock Reservoir Outlet Chlorination Station is not subject to Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations.  However, in the excess of caution, the LADWP decided to prepare a Program Level 3 RMP in 2009.  Thus, this 2014 update of the 2009 RMP demonstrates compliance with the Program Level 3 requirements.

The following information is specifically required in the RMP Update Executive Summary: 

¿	Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.
¿	General facility and regu

lated substances information.
¿	Summary of the accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps.
¿	Five-year accident history summary.
¿	Emergency response program summary.
¿	Planned changes to improve safety.

The above information for the Eagle Rock Reservoir Outlet Chlorination Station is provided below.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
The LADWP accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates the use of proven technology, trains staff in operation and maintenance practices, and uses tested and proven management system practices.  All applicable requirements of the State of California and the EPA's Prevention Program are adhered to, including key elements such as training, systems management, and emergency response procedures.  

The LADWP emergency response policy involves the preparation of emergency response plans for hazardous materials which are tailored to each facility and to the emergency response services available in the community, and is in compliance with the EPA and the CalARP Program Emergency Response Program Requirements.  The LADWP has prepared an Emergency Response Plan for the Eagle Rock Reservoir Outlet Chlorination Station to facilitate coordination and emergency planning with offsite response officials and facilities in the event of an emergency.  The Emergency Response Plan has been coordinated with the local response agency (City of Los Angeles Fire Department).  The Eagle Rock Chlorination Station has a good record in preventing accidents from occurring. 

General Facility and Regulated Substance Information
The Eagle Rock Reservoir Outlet Chlorination Station is located at 5403 Hillmont Avenue in Eagle Rock, next to the Ventura Freeway.  This facility serves to chlorinate the reservoir, one inlet line, and two discharge lines.  The water serves the northern and eastern Los Angeles area. The station consists of a chlorine container and

chlorination room, a pump room, a main chlorine scrubber, and a mini- scrubber.  The facility currently stores chlorine, a regulated toxic substance under the EPA and the CalARP Program rules. A maximum of seven one-ton chlorine containers is stored at the Eagle Rock Reservoir Outlet Chlorination station.  Six of these chlorine containers can be connected to the chlorination process to feed liquid and gaseous chlorine and one is stored as a spare. The one-ton container is the largest vessel (container) online. The maximum quantity of chlorine present at the Eagle Rock Reservoir Outlet Chlorination Station at any given time exceeds the listed threshold quantities in the EPA and the CalARP regulations.  It also exceeds the listed threshold quantities in the federal and the California Occupational Safety and Health Administration (CalOSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Standards. However, the facility is normally unoccupied and water treatment operators visit the facility daily and respond to any trouble alarms that may occur.  Thus, the LADWP Eagle Rock Reservoir Outlet Chlorination Station is not subject to the federal or the California OSHA PSM regulations.

In normal operations, six chlorine one-ton containers are manifolded together in two banks of three containers to supply chlorine.  These six containers are equipped with Halogen actuators on the angle valves and will close the valves when a chlorine concentration of 10 ppm is detected in the room.  The primary bank is connected to the liquid header and the secondary bank is connected to the gas header.  The liquid chlorine passes from the containers to the evaporator where it is vaporized in a water bath.  The gaseous chlorine then proceeds to one of the four chlorinators that regulate the flow of chlorine. The gas supplying containers bypass the evaporators, serving as an automatic backup when the primary containers run dry or the evaporator shuts down due to a low temperature condition.  Space is allocat

ed in the room for the storage of one additional container that is not provided with a connection to the chlorination system.  
The gas header line is equipped with automatic switchover vacuum regulating valves (a combination of evaporator actuated vacuum regulating valve with check-relief unit and standby vacuum regulating valve with check-relief vent), and pressure gauges.  The liquid header line is equipped with pressure gauges and an expansion chamber to protect against excessive pressure.  The primary (liquid) bank provides all the chlorine to the station through the evaporators until it is depleted.  The gaseous chlorine bank automatically starts supplying chlorine when the primary bank is depleted.  This automatic system is achieved by setting the automatic vacuum regulating valve leading from the secondary bank to standby.  Once the primary bank is depleted, the higher vacuum level acts on the diaphragm of the automatic switchover vacuum regulator in the secondary bank, thereby pulling that valve open to start feeding gas.

The gaseous chlorine from the evaporators or from the chlorine gas header proceeds to the chlorinators that regulate the flow of chlorine.  Chlorine gas from the vacuum regulating valve with check-relief units is pulled by vacuum to the chlorinators and then to the injectors. It is important to note that in case of loss of vacuum downstream of the vacuum regulating valve with check-relief unit, air would be drawn in rather than chlorine being released and the vacuum regulating valve with check-relief unit will shut down the chlorine supply to the chlorinator, operating as a shut-off valve. 

The gaseous chlorine is pulled by vacuum from the chlorinators to injectors where it is dissolved into mixing water to form a concentrated solution.  For reservoir treatment, the injector is located on the shore next to the reservoir.  For the two discharge lines, the injectors are located inside the chlorine room.  The concentrated solution is t

hen piped into the reservoir through a diffuser, or into the discharge water through numerous diffusion points. The treated water is then piped into the distribution network. 
Residual chlorine analyzers monitor residual chlorine in the pipeline downstream of the diffusers and provide feedback control for subsequent chlorine dosing.  Dosing is also controlled in response to flowrate.   

Multiple chlorine leak detectors have been installed to detect chlorine inside and outside the building which alarm locally as well as at the Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant (LAAFP) Control Room at Sylmar. 
The Eagle Rock Reservoir Outlet Chlorination Station has installed a dry media chlorine main scrubber actuated by the chlorine detectors at a chlorine concentration of 3 ppm that can neutralize up to 2,000 lb of chlorine.

A dry media chlorine "mini-scrubber" unit (MS) has also been installed at the Eagle Rock Reservoir Outlet Chlorination Station.  The MS is an emergency chlorine scrubber intended to protect personnel working in the building or immediate area from a chlorine gas release from the pressure safety relief vent provided in the vacuum regulator check units. Mini-scrubber can neutralize up to 25 lbs of chlorine. The media manufacturer specifies chlorine removal to less than 5 parts per billion. The mini-scrubber is activated automatically at a chlorine concentration of 1 ppm.

In the event power is lost at the Eagle Rock Reservoir Outlet Chlorination Station, an alarm will alert the LAAFP control room.  The chlorine flow will continue unaffected, with no safety consequences. In addition, loss of power will cause the emergency generator to take over powering the entire station.
The facility is normally unoccupied; water treatment operators visit the facility daily. A response team coordinated from the LADWP Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant (LAAFP) responds to any trouble alarms that may occur. Access to the facility is through gates that are kept loc

ked at all times.

Summary of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The LADWP accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:

¿	Detailed management system and clear levels of responsibilities and team member roles.
¿	Comprehensive process safety information that is readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors.
¿	Comprehensive preventive maintenance program.
¿	Performance of process hazard analysis review of equipment and procedures with operation and maintenance staff participation and review.
¿	State-of-the-art process and safety equipment.
¿	Accurate and effective operating procedures, written with the participation of the station operators.
¿	High level training for the operators and maintenance staff.
¿	A State of California Water Treatment Facility Staff Certification is required to operate the station.
¿	An incident investigation, inspection, and auditing program using qualified staff.

Chemical-specific prevention steps include the following: availability of self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA), worn by the operators during connection/disconnection of chlorine supply; awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of chlorine; presence of chlorine detectors with remote monitoring; use of Halogen actuators on ton containers; a chlorine main scrubber; and a chlorine mini-scrubber.

Process and Chemical Safety Information
Comprehensive chemical data has been assembled to include regulatory reporting and action thresholds, health hazard, and chemical exposure limitations, as well as detailed physical properties of chlorine.  This information includes chlorine background information and MSDS sheets.
Equipment safety information was compiled on the chlorination process. Specifications for the chlorination process are collected and provided in one place for easy reference. Details (such as maximum intended inventory; safe upper and lower temperat

ures; and safe upper and lower pressures for the chlorination facility) are on file at the facility.  The LADWP also has procedures in place that are triggered to update process safety information if there is a major change that makes existing information inaccurate.

Process Hazard Analysis 
In 1993, a detailed hazard review/Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was conducted for the chlorination system equipment and procedures. The 1993 hazard review/PHA was further reviewed in April 1999. In April 2004 a hazard review/PHA was again performed for the whole chlorination system.  The 2004 hazard review/PHA for the facility was further reviewed in March 2009. The 2009 PHA was again reviewed on March 14, 2014 and will be updated again within a five-year period or whenever there will be a major change in the process.  A list of recommended actions was developed in March 2014 to further improve the chlorine safety and staff is currently evaluating these recommendations.  Staff will document the completion of the recommended actions.

A seismic walkthrough was completed on March 4, 2014 based on the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) Region 1 guidance document, and recommendations are being evaluated for implementation. 

Operating Procedures
The LADWP has prepared written operating procedures for Eagle Rock Reservoir Outlet Chlorination Station that provide clear instructions or steps for safely conducting activities relating to chlorination process. They are consistent with the chlorine safety information. Written operating procedures included in the facility's Operation and Maintenance (O&M) Manual are as follows:

¿	Delivery of Chlorine.
¿	Container Connections.
¿	Initial Startup Procedure.
¿	Normal Operation. 
¿	Normal Shutdown. 
¿	Temporary Operations. 
¿	Emergency Operations. 
¿	Emergency Shutdown. 
¿	Startup Following Emergency Shutdown. 

Training 
The LADWP ensures that each employee operating or maintaining the chlorination process, and eac

h employee newly assigned to this process, is trained and tested for competency in the operating procedures listed above. The LADWP employee training documentation files include training records for each employee assigned to operate or maintain the chlorination process. The training ensures that the employee has the required knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely perform the duties and responsibilities, including chlorine emergency response, as provided in the operating procedures.  Employee training includes, as a minimum, the following elements:

¿	Safety Information.
¿	Process Technology and Process Equipment, including safety systems.
¿	Maintenance Procedures.
¿	Operating Procedures for the chlorine system.
¿	RMP Program contents.
¿	Emergency Response Plan and Procedures.

Refresher training is provided at least every three years to each employee operating the chlorination process to ensure that the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures. In addition, the LADWP ensures that operators are trained in any updated or new procedures before startup of a process after major modifications.

Contractors
The LADWP contractors' procedures specify the information required to be provided to the contractors performing work on or near the chlorination process, the training requirements for contractor employees, and mechanism to obtain assurance from contractors that they have informed their employees of the appropriate safety rules.  The LADWP provides information and explanations concerning the hazards and processes. 

Pre-Startup Safety Review and Mechanical Integrity Program
The LADWP has procedures in place to ensure that a pre-startup safety review is conducted prior to starting a new covered process or prior to making modifications to the chlorination systems that require a Management of Change (MOC) procedure implementation.  The required conditions prior to startup include the following:

¿	Construction and/or equipmen

t are in accordance with design specifications.
¿	Safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate.
¿	A PHA has been performed for new facilities and recommendations have been resolved or implemented before startup.
¿	At modified facilities, MOC requirements have been met.
¿	Training of each operating and maintenance employee involved in the process is complete.

These procedures ensure that no new and/or significantly modified process will startup and no regulated substances will be introduced into such a process before the pre-startup safety review.  This constitutes a final check that the process and equipment are ready to go and that the recommendations of the PHA have been implemented or adequately addressed.  This will ensure that the design and construction of a new or modified process is safely executed and that the facility is prepared to operate it. 

Mechanical integrity procedures for the plant ensure that written maintenance procedures are implemented and documented, including training of maintenance personnel.

Maintenance 
The LADWP operates a maintenance program, MAXIMO Program that generates a work order for performing the preventive maintenance routine, which occurs after a designated time past the closing of the previous work order for that particular maintenance process.  Description of the work to be performed is included with the printed work order.  The water treatment supervisors are responsible for the maintenance of the chlorination system.  

In addition, the written maintenance procedure is provided in the O&M Manual as follows: Preventive maintenance schedules are provided which summarize inspection, test, and maintenance schedules on a daily, weekly, bimonthly, monthly, biannual, and annual, every 2 to 10 years, and on as-needed basis.  These procedures allow the operator to rapidly review what maintenance is necessary.  The schedules are supplemental to the log sheets onsite and provid

e a summary and quick reference to manufacturer's O&M manuals.  A maintenance log book is provided on-site for Operator quick reference. 
The LADWP documents inspection, testing, and maintenance of chlorination equipment and assures the performance is performed in accordance with the recommendations of the manufacturer and industry groups (i.e., Chlorine Institute).

Hot Work Permits and Management of Change 
Hot work refers to work involving electric or gas welding, cutting, brazing, or similar flame or spark producing operations.  The hot work procedures require the issuance of a hot work permit whenever it is conducted on or near the chlorination process and other areas deemed appropriate as described in these procedures.  Fire prevention and protection systems are in place before a hot work permit is issued. The permit indicates the dates the work is authorized for, the location, and specific operational requirements, and it is kept on file in the administrative office. 

The LADWP Management of Change procedures include steps required to be taken by plant personnel before implementing changes to chlorination equipment, procedures, raw materials, and processing conditions.  Training, process safety information, operating procedures, and maintenance procedures are updated according to the changes made.

Internal Compliance Audits
The LADWP has been certifying every three years (or earlier) that compliance with Program 2 Prevention Program requirements is met and that procedures and practices developed are adequate and being followed. Starting June 2009, the LADWP certified compliance with Program 3 Prevention Program requirements. The two most recent audit reports and a list of the recommendations are retained in the LADWP's files.

The compliance audit consists of separating the RMP program elements or sections, and auditing each element to determine compliance and effectiveness.  For each internal audit, the audit team completes a Compliance Audit Ce

rtification Page and a Compliance Audit Checklist.  The Compliance Audit Certification Page provides process identification, the dates of the audit, team members, and certification by the audit leader.  The Compliance Audit Checklist details the requirements of each RMP element and contains questions that may assist with the auditing process. The audit checklist for each element consists of the following three sections:

¿	Records Review: A review of the RMP written Prevention Program.
¿	Onsite Conditions: The audit team reviews the program elements based on observation of the plant conditions and safety practices.
¿	Interviews:  The program elements are evaluated by interviewing personnel from appropriate functions including operations, maintenance, management, and contractors.
Team members record RMP program deficiencies identified during the audit on the checklist.

Incident Investigation
The LADWP incident investigation procedures describe incident reporting, investigation, and investigation reporting steps to be followed by plant personnel.  The incident investigation is started promptly but no later than 48 hours after the event.  The LADWP promptly addresses and resolves all recommendations and shall implement the recommendations in a timely manner to prevent an incident recurrence.  All incident investigation reports are retained in the LADWP's file for at least a period of five years from the date the reports are completed.

Five-year Accident History Summary
No chlorine releases that could have caused safety or health hazard (deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage evacuations, or sheltering in place) occurred at the Eagle Rock Reservoir Outlet Chlorination Station during the last five years.

Emergency Response Program Summary
The LADWP is a first responder, its employees respond to chlorine accidental releases.  In the event an accidental release that could result in offsite consequences occurs, external resources, such as the Ci

ty of Los Angeles Fire Department will also be solicited to respond.  
As part of the emergency response program, the LADWP has developed and implemented an emergency response plan for the purpose of protecting public health and the environment.  The following elements are included:

(a)	An emergency response plan, maintained at the Eagle Rock Reservoir Outlet Chlorination Station  and at the Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant (LAAFP) containing:
¿	Organizational structure (chain-of-command) and responsibilities of various LADWP personnel.
¿	Procedures for planning and coordination with off-site emergency response organizations.
¿	Details of the training programs for all employees involved with the chlorination process, contractor training, and medical surveillance of LADWP personnel who respond to chlorine releases.
¿	Details of emergency recognition and prevention at the LADWP.
¿	Procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies about accidental releases.
¿	Documentation of proper first aid and emergency medical treatment necessary to treat accidental human exposures and the detailed information on emergency health care.
¿	Procedures and measures for emergency response after an accidental release.

(b)	Procedures for the use of emergency response equipment and for its inspection, testing, and maintenance. 
(c)	Training in relevant procedures for all employees involved with the chlorination process.
(d)	Procedures to review and update, as appropriate, the emergency response plan to reflect changes and ensure that employees are informed of changes.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
As part of updating the 2004 Risk Management Program, a PHA was performed in 2009 for the chlorination system. Based on the 2009 PHA, a few equipment and procedural changes were recommended. All the above recommendations have been evaluated and implemented by the LADWP, including the installation and operation of a dry media chlorine mini-scrub

ber. Additionally, five recommendations to further improve chlorine safety were identified in March 2014, when the PHA was reviewed for the facility. Based on the 2014 seismic assessment, two recommendations were made to improve chlorine safety. It is expected that all the recommendations will be evaluated by December 2014 and implemented by June 2015. The implementation of these recommendations will further improve the safety of the chlorination system.
